fields.Title of Presentation: Program design and intervention control sequences for sustained  suppression of transmission in two high ­burden Ugandan  subcounties, an operational research study guided by simulation
fields.Conference / Meeting Name: American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene
fields.Description/Abstract:
Despite a history of control measures, many communities in northern Uganda have very high levels of parasite transmission and malaria-associated morbidity and mortality. We report on the inception of a collaborative and multi-faceted
project conducted in the Katakwi district in northeastern Uganda designed to
rapidly decrease and sustain community-wide parasite burden. The architecture
of this program has in part been guided by simulation, using model strategic
approaches for intervention timing and projected impact. A first phase of the
program deploys a sequence of interventions which include both vector control
and chemoprevention, timed for high potential impact and aimed to quickly and
markedly reduce transmission. Particular emphasis is laid on the strong synergy between MDA + IRS when deployed simultaneously. A second phase of the program attempts to sustain gains through a community-supported active-case infrastructure. Some progress and simulation-guided results and program design generalizations will be reported.
